text: All coursework must be submitted by the published deadline through the official submission system.
Late submissions will be penalised at a rate of 10% per 24 hours, up to a maximum of five working days, after which a mark of zero will be recorded.
Extensions may only be granted for approved mitigating circumstances and must be requested in advance of the deadline.
Feedback on coursework should normally be provided within 10 working days of submission.
All marks are provisional until confirmed by the Board of Examiners.
Students who experience unforeseen events that significantly impact assessment performance may submit a mitigating circumstances claim.
Claims must be submitted within five working days of the affected assessment unless there are compelling reasons for delay.
Appropriate evidence, such as a medical certificate, must be provided to support the claim.
Accepted claims may result in deadline extensions or resit opportunities without penalty.
Students are expected to attend all scheduled teaching sessions, laboratory sessions, and tutorials.
Persistent non-attendance without authorisation may lead to disciplinary action or withdrawal from the programme.
Students must notify their department in advance if they are unable to attend due to illness or exceptional circumstances.
Attendance records are monitored and may be reviewed as part of academic progress meetings.
All students must submit original work and correctly acknowledge all sources used in assignments.
Plagiarism, collusion, or fabrication of data are considered serious academic offences.
Suspected cases of misconduct will be investigated according to the College’s disciplinary procedures.
Penalties for academic misconduct may include mark reduction, failure of a module, or expulsion from the College.
Students are expected to behave respectfully towards all members of the College community.
Harassment, discrimination, or bullying of any kind will not be tolerated and may result in disciplinary proceedings.
The College reserves the right to take disciplinary action for behaviour that damages its reputation.
Students must comply with all health and safety requirements in laboratories and workshops.
Students must bring their College ID card to all examinations and display it on their desk.
Electronic devices, including mobile phones and smartwatches, must be switched off and placed away from the exam desk.
Students arriving more than 30 minutes late will not be permitted to enter the examination room.
Leaving the examination room during the first 45 minutes is not permitted except for emergencies.
Any suspected misconduct during exams will be reported to the Academic Integrity Panel.
All students must complete the mandatory safety induction before accessing laboratories or workshops.
Personal protective equipment must be worn in designated areas as instructed by supervisors.
Students must immediately report accidents, injuries, or near misses to a member of staff.
Unsafe behaviour or repeated breaches of safety regulations may result in loss of lab access privileges.
Library materials must be returned or renewed by the due date to avoid fines.
Access to College IT systems is provided for academic purposes only and must comply with the Acceptable Use Policy.
Sharing login credentials or using another person’s account is strictly prohibited.
Downloading or distributing copyrighted material without permission is not allowed.
Residents must pay accommodation fees according to the schedule set out in their licence agreement.
Noise levels must be kept low between 11 p.m. and 7 a.m. to respect other residents.
Tampering with fire safety equipment is a disciplinary offence and may lead to eviction.
Visitors are allowed only with prior permission from the hall supervisor.
Students experiencing difficulties should contact the Student Support Services for confidential advice.
The College provides counselling, wellbeing workshops, and academic mentoring services.
Reasonable adjustments will be made for students with registered disabilities or long-term health conditions.
All support requests must be accompanied by appropriate documentation, such as a medical report.
The College collects and processes personal data in accordance with the UK General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).
Students have the right to access, correct, or request deletion of their personal data held by the College.
Personal data must not be shared with unauthorised third parties without consent or legal basis.
Data breaches must be reported to the College Data Protection Officer immediately upon discovery.
